title: 107_s2710
content: The Act titled "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" provides a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under SEC. 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" offers a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under SEC. 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit is determined based on the amount paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year for qualified employee health insurance expenses, with the applicable percentage varying based on the number of qualified employees and their average annual rate of wages. The applicable percentage is determined by a formula involving the number of qualified employees, average annual rate of wages, and a threshold of $10,000. The applicable percentage for the tax credit is zero if determined under certain conditions. For employers with up to 50 qualified employees with average annual wages below $30,000, the applicable percentage is at least 5 percent. There is also a per-employee dollar limitation for qualified employee health expenses. The per-employee dollar limitation for qualified employee health insurance expenses is $2,000 for self-only coverage and $5,000 for family coverage. The limitation for qualified employee health insurance expenses is determined based on the portion of the taxable year and the average number of employees in the preceding calendar years. The determination of employee health insurance expenses is based on the average number of employees in the preceding calendar years, taking into account the employer's existence throughout those years. If the employer was not in existence in the 1st preceding calendar year, the determination is based on the expected average number of employees. The term 'qualified employee health insurance expenses' refers to amounts paid by an employer for health insurance coverage provided to at least 50% of qualified employees, excluding amounts paid under salary reduction arrangements. The term 'qualified employee' refers to an employee who works more than 30 hours per week for the employer, excluding those eligible for subsidized health plans. The term 'qualified employee' refers to an employee who works more than 30 hours per week for the employer and meets certain criteria such as entitlement to benefits under specific titles of the Social Security Act or eligibility for benefits under specific chapters of the United States Code. The amendment to Section 38(b) includes the credit as part of the general business credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include the employee health insurance expenses credit under section 45G. No carryback of the section 45G credit is allowed before the effective date. The unused business credit for any taxable year related to the employee health insurance expenses credit under section 45G cannot be carried back before January 1, 2003. The amendments made by this section apply to small business employee health insurance expenses incurred after December 31, 2002, for coverage established after the enactment of this Act.
